The chlorine atom, being a halogen, is highly electronegative and contributes to a higher melting point by inducing dipole-dipole interactions. A chloro substituent typically increases a molecule's melting point by around 20 ºC. However, combining these factors leads to an overestimation, as is evident from the actual value which is lower. This discrepancy can arise from the spatial arrangement of the substituents generating steric hindrance, which may destabilize the solid lattice structure and reduce the melting point. Moreover, an isopropyl group adjacent to a chlorine may interfere with the crystal packing, lowering the expected increase from these substituents individually.
